newsitem.title: CHINA: China says some state firms go bankrupt illegally.
newsitem.headline: China says some state firms go bankrupt illegally.

text.p: Many state-owned firms in China have illegally declared bankruptcy, clearing their debts only to resume loss-making operations, the official People's Daily said on Monday.
Many firms had cleared their debts through bankruptcy but then continued to operate, losing more money and draining state assets, the newspaper said.
It did not name any such companies and did not explain how they could stay in business, saying only they had declared bankruptcy as a way of shedding mountains of debt.
"Bankrupt enterprises must really be bankrupt, workers must be relocated and enterprises must close down," the newspaper said of the use of the bankruptcy law.

China had to proceed slowly with bankruptcies, the newspaper said, adding that the closure of state-run factories would throw many people out of work before there was a social safety net in place to catch them.
"For a long time to come, state-run industrial enterprises will be unable to declare bankruptcy based on debt-asset ratios and operational situations as in Western market economies," it said.
The average debt-asset ratio of state-owned industrial enterprises was 80 percent, it said, adding that most of that debt was owed to state banks.
Vice-premier and economic tzar Zhu Rongji recently called on ailing state enterprises to avoid bankruptcies and seek mergers when they were in financial difficulty.
China passed a bankruptcy law in 1988 as the first part of an ambitious drive to force lumbering state-owned enterprises to sink or swim in the market place.
It has generally used bankruptcies only for smaller enterprises but the number of firms pushed out of business under the legal framework has been growing.
In the first half of this year, 1,692 enterprises declared bankruptcy, more than double the figure for the year-ago period, official figures show.
